Headline: CEO at Stealth Mode Startup
Comment:
Interesting topic here ‚Äî and the time is right to discuss it before calmness turns into chaos.
Here's my take:
Valuation wasn‚Äôt born in the founder‚Äôs pitch deck, yet it‚Äôs become the default yardstick for startups ‚Äî often the first question asked, even before the product demo is over.
This obsession didn‚Äôt start with founders. It took hold when big consulting firms and investment banks pushed ‚Äúvaluation-led growth‚Äù as the norm. Useful for M&A and IPO prep, but that mindset spilled into the early-stage world.
Founders trying to solve real problems were pushed to tell a ‚Äúvaluation story‚Äù instead of a value creation one. And when valuation becomes the goal, it distorts priorities ‚Äî growth at all costs, inflated forecasts, premature scaling.
It‚Äôs time to stop placing all the blame on founders. The narrative was shaped by those who benefited most from valuations on paper.
Valuation has its place. But the real scoreboard? Revenue, Retention, and Relevance.
processed_comment: interesting topic here and the time is right to discuss it before calmness turns into chaos heres my take valuation wasnt born in the founders pitch deck yet its become the default yardstick for startups often the first question asked even before the product demo is over this obsession didnt start with founders it took hold when big consulting firms and investment banks pushed valuationled growth as the norm useful for ma and ipo prep but that mindset spilled into the earlystage world founders trying to solve real problems were pushed to tell a valuation story instead of a value creation one and when valuation becomes the goal it distorts priorities growth at all costs inflated forecasts premature scaling its time to stop placing all the blame on founders the narrative was shaped by those who benefited most from valuations on paper valuation has its place but the real scoreboard revenue retention and relevance

Comment:
Loved this, Rishabh.
Raising high feels like winning until you realise you just raised the bar¬†you¬†have to jump next. I have seen friends raise at great optics but then spend 12+ months playing catch up to their own cap table. That‚Äôs a treadmill, not traction.
The best raise with clarity, not ego. Milestones over multiples. Room to grow instead of pressure to perform magic. Valuation isn‚Äôt a finish line, it‚Äôs the start of a new clock. Make sure it gives you time to build, not burn.

Headline: CEO @ [Coming Soon] | Building Ecosystems, Not Just Startups | Designing Growth Engines Across Markets, Capital & People
Comment:
Valuation¬†is¬†a milestone; if you¬†earned¬†it.
Not with decks, dreams, and decibels; but with¬†distribution, data, and demand.
You say $2M at $30M post is irresponsible. I say it's irresponsible¬†only if¬†your company was all bark and no bite.
But if you‚Äôve got the market by its throat,
If you know how to¬†create the narrative and own the outcome,
Then¬†valuation is your playground; and you better play big.
The future doesn‚Äôt belong to those who ‚Äúprice for where they are.‚Äù
It belongs to those who¬†price for where the market is going; and then¬†drag reality to match it.
Stop training founders to be¬†"reasonable."
The next unicorns won‚Äôt come from caution.
They‚Äôll come from¬†clarity,¬†conviction, and the courage to bet on themselves¬†before¬†anyone else sees it.
So yeah; valuation is a responsibility.
But it‚Äôs also a weapon.
Use it like one.
